moves.1. d4 h6: This is called the Carr Defense when played against 1.e4.
moves.2. e4 e6 3. Nf3 Nf6 4. Bd3 Be7 5. Nc3 O-: Black is passive, but both sides are relatively solid.
moves.7. Bf4: Taking control of the important e5 square.
moves.7... Nbd7 8. Qd2: Setting up a future kingside attack and connecting the rooks.
moves.9. dxe5 Nxe5 10. Bxe5 Bg4: Black probably thought I was going to retreat the bishop, but instead allows me to go on an eating frenzy.
moves.14. f4 c6 15. Kh1: Readying the rook to come to g1.
moves.15... b5 16. Rfg1 a5 17. e5: Sacrificing a pawn for open lines for my bishop.
moves.17... dxe5 18. fxe5 Qe6 19. Rg3 b4 20. R: No need to worry about the knight. Mate is much more important.
